title: How to Get Rid of Fleas on Humans

steps.title: Fleas often bite at night, so they might be living in your bedding.
steps.content: Fleas often bite at night, so they might be living in your bedding. Strip your bed and wash your blanket, sheets, and pillow cases on the hottest setting you have. This will kill any fleas and eggs that could be in your bed, so it should get rid of the problem quickly. [1] X Trustworthy Source United States Environmental Protection Agency Independent U.S. government agency responsible for promoting safe environmental practices Go to source If you have fleas in your bed, you probably have them elsewhere in your home, too.

steps.title: Sometimes, simply vacuuming your carpet is enough to get rid of fleas.
steps.content: Sometimes, simply vacuuming your carpet is enough to get rid of fleas . Use a vacuum and go over your entire carpet, and don’t forget any rugs, too! When you’re done vacuuming, empty the contents into a sealed plastic bag and dispose of it outside right away. [2] X Research source The vacuum will suck up the fleas, but it won’t kill them. That’s why it’s important to seal and trash the vacuum waste quickly—otherwise, the fleas will simply hop out and infest your home again.

steps.title: Fleas sometimes hang out in hard-to-reach areas.
steps.content: Fleas sometimes hang out in hard-to-reach areas. If you’ve vacuumed your carpet but you're still getting bitten, use a hose attachment on your vacuum and go over any soft furniture and along the baseboards. This will also remove any eggs that the fleas might have laid before you managed to get to them. [3] X Expert Source Kevin Carrillo Pest Control Specialist Expert Interview. 5 November 2019. Again, be sure to empty your vacuum contents into a sealed bag and throw it away outside quickly. That way, the fleas will be out of your home.

steps.title: The heat combined with the carpet cleaner will kill any fleas and eggs.
steps.content: The heat combined with the carpet cleaner will kill any fleas and eggs. Buy or rent a steam cleaner from your local hardware store and fill it up with carpet cleaner. Go over your entire carpet, and don’t forget to use it underneath furniture, too. [4] X Expert Source Kevin Carrillo Pest Control Specialist Expert Interview. 5 November 2019. You can find decent carpet cleaners for around $200 if you want to buy one. Or, you can rent one for around $30 per day. If you have a large house, you may want to look into hiring a professional carpet cleaner instead of doing it yourself.

steps.title: More often than not, the fleas in your home are on your pets.
steps.content: More often than not, the fleas in your home are on your pets. If you have cats or dogs, treat them with flea medicine either from your vet or from the pet store. These topical medications will infect the fleas as they bite your pet, and the fleas will usually die off in a couple of days. [5] X Expert Source Kevin Carrillo Pest Control Specialist Expert Interview. 5 November 2019. Be sure to read the dosage recommendation on the back of the flea medication. Larger animals need more, while smaller animals need less. You can also take your pet to the vet and put them on oral flea medication. Talk to your veterinarian to see if that’s the right move for you. [6] X Research source

steps.title: For a more natural way to get rid of fleas, buy a flea comb from the pet store.
steps.content: For a more natural way to get rid of fleas, buy a flea comb from the pet store. Start at your pet’s neck, then slowly stroke the comb backwards in the direction that their hair grows. Keep a bowl of soapy water next to you—if any fleas come off on the comb, hold them underwater for a minute or so to drown them. [7] X Expert Source Kevin Carrillo Pest Control Specialist Expert Interview. 5 November 2019. Flea combs also pull out flea eggs and flea dirt (flea poop). You may want to wear gloves and lay an old towel down before you start. [8] X Trustworthy Source The Humane Society of the United States National organization devoted to the promotion of animal welfare Go to source

steps.title: Grab their bed and any blankets they sleep on.
steps.content: Grab their bed and any blankets they sleep on. Throw them into the washer, then run a cycle on the hottest setting you have. The hot water will drown and kill the fleas, and it will also wash away any eggs they might have laid on the bedding. [9] X Expert Source Kevin Carrillo Pest Control Specialist Expert Interview. 5 November 2019. Try to wash your pets’ bedding at least once a week to prevent a flea infestation. [10] X Trustworthy Source American Kennel Club The American Kennel Club (AKC) is a purebred dog pedigree registry in the United States. The AKC advocates for the responsible ownership of dogs and promotes purebred dog events, such as the Westminster Dog Show. Go to source If your pet has a litter box, clean that out with soap and water, too.

steps.title: If you’re attracting fleas outside, use bug spray whenever you go out.
steps.content: If you’re attracting fleas outside, use bug spray whenever you go out. Experts recommend using DEET, since it’s very effective against most pests. Focus the bug spray on your feet and ankles, since that’s where fleas like to bite the most. If the fleas are living outdoors, they’ll probably be in tall grass or under large bushes. You should definitely use bug spray if you plan on walking through any overgrown wooded areas.

steps.title: These non-toxic traps kill adult fleas.
steps.content: These non-toxic traps kill adult fleas. Buy some flea traps and set them up in areas where you see the most fleas, like near your pets’ bedding. The traps will emit light and warmth to attract the fleas, but will trap them with a sticky paper insert. When the paper insert gets too full of fleas, you can take it out and replace it. [11] X Trustworthy Source National Resources Defence Council Multinational environmental advocacy group focused on grassroots activism and legislative action Go to source Flea traps work for smaller infestations , but since they don’t kill flea eggs, they aren’t a great method for larger infestations.

steps.title: Attract the fleas and drown them with soapy water.
steps.content: Attract the fleas and drown them with soapy water. Mix warm water with a few drops of dish soap in a shallow bowl or plate. Place your dish on the floor, then set a desk lamp next to it overnight. The fleas will be attracted to the light and the warmth from the lamp, and they’ll hop into the soapy water and drown. [12] X Research source In the morning, simply dump the water mixture down the sink. You can use this trap multiple times if you’re still finding fleas in your home.

steps.title: Fleas are repulsed by the strong scent of essential oils.
steps.content: Fleas are repulsed by the strong scent of essential oils. In a spray bottle, mix together 1 c (240 mL) of water with 7 drops each of rosemary, peppermint, eucalyptus, tea tree, and citronella essential oil. Shake up the bottle to mix them together, then use it as a natural flea repellent around your house. [13] X Research source If you have cats, don’t spray essential oils around them, as they are sensitive to the strong smells.

steps.title: Spot treat areas where you’ve noticed the fleas like to gather.
steps.content: Spot treat areas where you’ve noticed the fleas like to gather. Usually, this will be in any areas your pets hang out in. There are a lot of pesticides that you can choose from, but you should find ones that contain boric acid, silica or diatomaceous earth to kill both adult fleas and their larvae. Spray or sprinkle the pesticides around your home according to the instructions on the package. [14] X Research source Before you use pesticides, always read the safety information on the package. Pesticides are toxic to children and animals, so keep them away from the area if you choose to use them. [15] X Trustworthy Source United States Environmental Protection Agency Independent U.S. government agency responsible for promoting safe environmental practices Go to source Pesticides normally take 2 to 4 hours to dry. After that, they’re generally safe to be around again. Wear gloves to protect your hands while using pesticides, and wear an N95 mask to avoid inhaling any harsh chemicals.

steps.title: Tall grass and bushes attract a lot of fleas.
steps.content: Tall grass and bushes attract a lot of fleas. If you notice that you’re getting bitten by fleas outside, you can use insecticides in either spray or powder form outdoors. Always read the label on the back, and keep pets and small children away from the insecticides while you use them. [16] X Research source You might have to apply insecticides a few times until they kill all of the fleas. Always wear gloves and long sleeves to protect your skin while using insecticides. Read the safety information on any insecticide you choose to use, and keep kids and pets away from the area. [17] X Trustworthy Source United States Environmental Protection Agency Independent U.S. government agency responsible for promoting safe environmental practices Go to source

steps.title: Flea bombs contain aerosol chemicals made specifically to kill fleas.
steps.content: Flea bombs contain aerosol chemicals made specifically to kill fleas. You can purchase a flea bomb and release it in your home, then leave for 2 to 4 hours. When you come back, the chemicals will have permeated your home and hopefully gotten rid of all the fleas. [18] X Expert Source Kevin Carrillo Pest Control Specialist Expert Interview. 5 November 2019. Experts note that flea bombs work best in conjunction with other methods. Since the chemicals only go up and out, they probably won’t kill fleas that are hiding under furniture or behind baseboards. Always keep flea bombs away from ignition sources, like pilot lights and power outlets. Before flea bombing, get everyone out of the house, including pets. When it’s time to go back in the house, open up all the doors and windows to let your home air out before entering. [19] X Trustworthy Source United States Environmental Protection Agency Independent U.S. government agency responsible for promoting safe environmental practices Go to source

steps.title: Large infestations can be hard to get rid of on your own.
steps.content: Large infestations can be hard to get rid of on your own. If you’re still finding itchy red bites on your arms or legs and you’ve tried multiple home remedies, look into hiring a professional exterminator. They can assess your home and figure out the method that will work to kill the fleas and get rid of them permanently. Exterminators usually charge between $100 and $400 depending on the infestation and house size.
